questions.text: Which of the following statements is false about positron emission tomography-computed tomography(PET-CT)?

choices.text: Enhanced whole body CT is followed by whole body PET imaging
It combines cross sectional anatomic information with metabolic information
Imaging is done after administration of oral glucose solution
Strenuous activity must be avoided prior to imaging

questions.solution:
Oral glucose solution is not given prior to PET-CT. Blood glucose should be in the normal range as FDG uptake is competitively inhibited by glucose. For this reason, the patient is asked to fast for 4-6 hrs prior to imaging.

Positron emission tomography - CT (PET-CT):

  • PET imaging is based on the detection of an injected positron-emitting radioactive tracer.
  • It relies on the coincidence detection of the annihilation photons (γ), which are released when a positron combines with an electron.
  • A glucose analogue called fluorodeoxyglucose (FDG) is used in PET imaging. FDG is taken up by metabolically active cells, where it undergoes phosphorylation to form FDG-6-phosphate. Unlike glucose, FDG-6-phosphate cannot undergo further metabolism and becomes trapped within the cell.
  • The trapped FDG-6-phosphate is detected by the PET scanner.
  • The combination of PET imaging with CT (PET-CT) combines the metabolic information (PET) with the cross-sectional anatomic information (CT).

Indications of PET-CT:

  • PET-CT is used in oncology imaging to detect malignant cells as they demonstrate increased glucose metabolism relative to normal tissues.
  • It is indicated for differentiation of a malignant from a benign lesion.
  • It is indicated in tumor staging and evaluation of tumor recurrence.

Technique:

  • The patient must be fasted for 4-6 hrs prior to imaging.
  • Strenuous activity must be avoided prior to imaging and after radioisotope injection to avoid physiological muscle FDG uptake.
  • Bladder catheterization or voiding prior to imaging, bowel opacification, or IV contrast medium are optional.
  • Before injecting FDG, the blood glucose level should be measured. It should be < 150 mg/dL. Good blood glucose control is essential as FDG uptake is competitively inhibited by glucose.
  • Imaging is started 60 minutes following FDG injection.

questions.text: During a postmortem examination, the forensic expert notices a cherry red discoloration over the dependent parts of the body. Which of the following conditions show this characteristic postmortem staining?
questions.solution:
Carbon monoxide poisoning shows the characteristic postmortem staining with bright cherry red discoloration.

Postmortem hypostasis/Postmortem staining/Postmortem lividity/Livor mortis/Suggilation refers to bluish-purple or reddish-purple discoloration of the superficial layers of the skin due to the collection of blood in toneless capillaries. 

It is an early postmortem change that occurs due to engorged vessels showing through the skin seen on the dependent parts due to the pooling of blood under the effect of gravity. 

This staining starts as mottled patches 1-3 hours following death and develops to a uniform area of staining in 3-6 hours. Full development and fixation of hypostasis occur within 6-12 hours. This finding usually develops within 4 hours and persists until putrefaction. Fixation of hypostasis occurs earlier in summer. It is delayed in asphyxial deaths and in intracranial lesions.  

Other options

Option A: Hydrogen sulphide poisoning shows characteristic blue-green staining. 

Option B: Clostridium perfringens infection shows pale bronze staining.

Option C: Phosphorus poisoning shows dark brown staining.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man comes with complaints of nasal stuffiness, watery discharge, and small grape-like masses protruding from both nostrils. He had similar complaints for which he was operated on  5 years ago. He has a history of dust allergy. On examination, multiple, pale masses are seen which do not bleed on probing. Which of these sites is unlikely to be the site of origin of these masses?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of ethmoidal nasal polyposis which does not originate from the maxillary sinus.

Ethmoidal polyps originate from the ethmoidal sinus, uncinate process, and the middle turbinate and middle meatus. Antrochoanal polyps are known to originate from the maxillary sinus. 

In the given scenario, the age of the patient, the presence of multiple, bilateral grape-like masses at the nostrils points towards the diagnosis of the ethmoidal polyp. The history of allergy on dust exposure and the history of recurrence are also more common in ethmoidal polyps.

Related Pearl: Ethmoidal polyps

  • Main etiological factor is allergy
  • Usually affects the middle-aged
  • Site of origin: Lateral wall of the nose
  • Clinical features: Nasal stuffiness, headache (due to sinusitis), sneezing, watery nasal discharge, anosmia/ hyposmia, mass protruding from the nasal cavity
  • Findings:
    • Anterior rhinoscopy: Multiple, bilateral polypi that are smooth, glistening, grape-like masses often pale in color
    • They may be sessile or pedunculated, insensitive to probing and do not bleed on touch
  • Investigation of choice: NCCT
  • Treatment of choice: FESS

Related Pearl: Antrochoanal Polyp

  • Main etiological factors: Infection and allergy
  • Usually affects children
  • Site of origin: Mucosa of the maxillary antrum
  • Clinical features:
    • Usually single and unilateral
    • Unilateral nasal obstruction which becomes bilateral when it grows posteriorly and obstructs opposite choana
    • Mucoid nasal discharge
    • Hyponasal voice
  • Findings:
    • Grows posteriorly and usually missed on anterior rhinoscopy
    • Posterior rhinoscopy: Globular mass filling the choana or nasopharynx
  • Investigation: Nasal endoscopy: Shows nasal polyps that are pale, gelatinous and pedunculated. NonContrast CT scan: Gives exquisite bony detail of the paranasal sinus anatomy. It is the primary diagnostic imaging modality.
  • Treatment of choice: FESS

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy presents with lesions as shown in the image below. Which of the following is false regarding his condition?

choices.text: There is perifollicular hyperkeratosis and keratotic papules
It is associated with liver cirrhosis and alcohol abuse
It can be seen in patients after bariatric surgery
It is predominantly associated with a deficiency of vitamin D

questions.solution:
The above image shows phrynoderma or toad skin. All the statements except statement 4 are true. Phrynoderma is predominantly associated with a deficiency of Vitamin A.  

Phrynoderma (toad skin) is common in children in the 5 - 15 year age group. Phrynoderma is not specific to vitamin A deficiency, it is also seen in other nutritional deficiencies including B complex, ribofla­vin, vitamin C, vitamin E, essential fatty acids, and malnutrition.

It is a non-specific finding that can be associated with: 

• Liver cirrhosis.
• Malabsorption syndromes.
• Anorexia nervosa.
• Alcohol abuse.
• Nutritional deficiency following bariatric surgery.

It manifests as groups of papules, with a central keratotic plug. The papules have a follicular distribution and give the skin a rough texture. The elbows and knees are the most commonly affected areas but the buttocks and extensor surfaces of the limbs may also be affected.

All patients with phrynoderma should have their Vitamin A levels measured. 

Treatment involves the correction of poor diet and administration of multivitamin preparations containing Vitamin A. 
For children above 8 years and adults - 100,000 units daily for 3 days, followed by 50,000 units daily for 2 weeks and then 10,000 units daily for 2 months till liver stores are replenished.

Related Pearl: Vitamin-A supplementation & treatment of Vitamin-A deficiency

questions.text: The histology slide of cartilage is given below.  Which of the following statements is incorrect about this type of cartilage?

choices.text: It predominantly consists of type II collagen

questions.solution:
The given image shows fibrocartilage. The incorrect statement about this cartilage is that it mainly contains type 2 collagen. A fibrocartilage contains both type 1 and 2 collagen but is predominantly made of type I collagen.

Fibrocartilage contains a mixture of white fibrous tissue and cartilaginous tissue. This mix of fibrous and cartilaginous components makes this tissue extremely tough and resilient. It consists of bundles of collagen fibres (both type I and II) with rows of chondrocytes present between the bundles. They are not covered by perichondrium.

On microscopy, fibrocartilage can be identified by the presence of chondrocytes and the matrix containing abundant collagen fibres. 

Fibrocartilage is found in:

  • Intervertebral discs
  • Pubic symphysis
  • Manubriosternal joint
  • Menisci of the knee
  • Glenoid and acetabular labra
  • The lining of the bony grooves for tendons
  • Articular disc of temporomandibular and sternoclavicular joint

The image below shows - hyaline cartilage, fibrocartilage, and elastic cartilage respectively. 

Related Pearl: Types of Cartilage

questions.text: A 48-year-old male patient is brought to the psychiatry OPD by his wife. He is convinced that the lead actress of a film he watched recently is deeply in love with him and wants to marry him. She also says that he is socially withdrawn and doesn't have many friends. Upon conducting a mental status examination, there are no other significant findings. What is the most likely diagnosis of this patient?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, the man has a false belief that his chairman wants to marry him, which is a delusion of love, also known as de Clérambault syndrome/erotomania /psychose passionelle.

Delusions are false beliefs that are firmly held despite objective and obvious contradictory proof. It can be present in conditions like schizophrenia, mania, major depressive disorders, and delusional disorders. 

The erotomania is more common in women but can be seen in men as well. The patient feels that someone, who is usually of a higher status, is deeply in love with them. Patients with this delusion are usually solitary, withdrawn, dependent, and sexually inhibited. It is usually sudden in onset and runs a chronic course. It is seen in conditions like schizophrenia, mood disorder, and other organic disorders.

Other options: 

Option B: Capgras syndrome is a delusion of misidentification. Here, the patient believes that a familiar person has been replaced by an exact double, i.e. an impostor.

Option C: In the delusion of reference, the patient believes that events, objects, or behaviour of others have a special significance to him. For, when he comes across people talking, he might assume that the discussion is about them.

Option D: Othello syndrome is the presence of marked morbid, pathological, or delusional jealousy. The patient here has doubts of infidelity, which is also known as conjugal paranoia. The person holds an abnormal belief that their spouse or partner is being unfaithful. 

Related Pearl: Types of delusions

THE TYPES OF DELUSIONS

Delusion of control

False belief that a person’s will, thoughts, or feelings are being controlled by external forces.

Delusion of grandeur or Megalomania 

Exaggerated conception of one’s importance, power, or identity.

Delusion of infidelity or morbid jealousy or Othello syndrome

False belief that one’s lover is unfaithful. Sometimes called pathological jealousy.

Delusion of love or erotomania

False belief that another person is in love with them. In De Clerambault syndrome, the woman believes that a man, frequently older and of higher status, is in love with her.

Delusion of misidentification 

Capgras syndrome: Belief that a familiar person has been replaced by an exact double i.e. an impostor.

Fregoli syndrome: Person holds a delusional belief that different people are in fact a single person who changes his or her appearance or is in disguise.

Nihilistic delusion 

False belief that oneself, others or the world, is non-existent or about to end. When nihilistic delusion is accompanied by ideas concerning bodily function failure e.g. putrefaction of intestine etc, it is called Cotard syndrome.

Delusion of infestation 

False belief that one is infested with small but visible organisms. As a monosymptomatic delusional disorder, this is called Ekbom syndrome. 

Delusion of persecution

The most common delusion. False belief of being harassed or persecuted.

Delusion of poverty

The person strongly believes they are financially incapacitated.

Delusion of reference

False belief that the behavior of others has a particular and unusual significance, usually of a negative nature. The person may falsely feel that others are talking about them (e.g. the people on television are talking to or about the person).  

Delusion of self-accusation

False feeling of remorse and guilt. Seen in depression with psychotic features.

Related Pearl: Disorders of thought and perception

DISORDERS OF THOUGHT

DISORDER OF STREAM OF THOUGHT

(A) Disorder of tempo

(i) Flight of Ideas

Continuous flow of rapid speech that jumps from topic to topic

  • "I like mangoes, the weather is nice, India is great"

(ii) Retardation of thinking

Slow speed of speech and a prolonged latent period before a response

  • "I went to the market (pause)......... the shop was closed"

(iii) Circumstantialities

Inclusion of irrelevant details and going on in a roundabout manner, but their thought ultimately reaches the answer

  • Doctor: "How did you get that bruise?"

  • Patient: "I woke up and had a cup of coffee, read the newspaper and went for a walk. It was a wonderful day in the park. I returned home and watched the TV. I took a nap in the afternoon after lunch. I slipped and fell in the bathroom. The fall gave me this bruise."

(iv) Clang associations

Jumping from one word to another irrelevant rhyming word

  • I am Sam...I like jam...I travel in a tram"

(B) Disorder of continuity

(i) Perseveration

Repetition of out of context words, phrases, or ideas beyond the point of relevance.

  • Q1. What's your name?: "Rahul"

  • Q2. Where are you from?: "Rahul"

  • Q3. How old are you?: "Rahul"

(ii) Thought blocking

A sudden disruption of thought or a break in the flow of ideas

  • "I went to the market (extreme silence)...................."

DISORDER OF FORM OF THOUGHT

(i) Tangentiality

In response to a question, the patient gives a reply that is appropriate to the general topic but does not answer the question exactly. The speech moves away from the actual answer.

  • Doctor: "Have you had any trouble sleeping lately?"
  • Patient: "I usually sleep in my bed, but now I'm sleeping on the sofa"

(ii) Derailment

A breakdown in both the logical connection between ideas and the overall sense of goal-directedness. The words make sentences, but the sentences do not make sense.

  • "Some people just don't understand why I had breakfast in America during the first world war"

(iii) Neologisms

Bringing in new words that do not exist.

  • The world is not 'gooder' for people like me"

(iv) Desultory thoughts

Speech is grammatically correct, however, sudden unrelated ideas force their way in from time to time.

  • My actual problem is that the people never understand me and my stomach feels like an empty bucket"

(v) Word salad

Using a mixture of unintelligible meaningless words and sentences

  • Tree bus rain food home car tiger"

DISORDER OF POSSESSION OF THOUGHT
A. Thought alienation

(i) Thought insertion

Thoughts are being inserted into the patient's mind and they recognize them as being foreign and coming from without any stimulus

  • "I have repeated thoughts of killing my neighbors and I believe aliens are putting these ideas into my head at night"

(ii) Thought withdrawal

Delusion that someone or something is removing from one's mind and the patient has no power over this.

  • "Lately, I am losing all my memories and I believe that the 'government agents' are stealing them when I go to sleep"

(iii) Thought broadcasting

Belief that one's thoughts are quietly escaping from one's mind and that other people might be able to access them and hear or see them.

  • "I believe my exact thoughts appear on the TV and the internet and I think I can broadcast them globally" 

(iv) Thought echo

Patient hears the 'echo' of his own thoughts in the form of a voice after he has made the thought.

  • "I thought of making a sandwich in the morning and surprisingly a voice, from nowhere, told me to make a sandwich out loud" 

 B. Obsessions and Compulsions

1. Obsessions

Recurrent and persistent thoughts, impulses. or images that cause distress to oneself.

  • Fear of dirt or contamination
  • Fear of becoming ill
  • Constant thoughts of a certain number
  • Need for symmetry or exactness
  • Worry about whether something has been done "right"
  • Forbidden sexual or religious thoughts

2. Compulsions

Repetitive behaviors or actions that the person feels driven to perform in response to an obsession

  • Washing hands
  • Blinking eyes
  • Counting items, such as currency
  • Checking to see if doors are locked
  • Arranging items in a certain way
  • Requiring constant approval from people around them

 
 DISORDER OF CONTENT OF THOUGHT

(i) Phobias

Persistent fear of an object or situation, typically disproportional to the actual danger posed, in which the sufferer goes to great lengths in avoiding it

  • Arachnophobia - fear of spider
  • Barophobia - fear of gravity
  • Cynophobia - fear of dogs
  • Hemophobia - fear of blood
  • Nosocomephobia - fear of hospitals

(ii) Religious preoccupations

Thoughts involving religious themes or subject matter.

  • "I get instructions from God on how to make my country great"

(iii) Ideas of hopelessness

Thoughts of complete despair where the patient strongly believes that the circumstances will never get better for him.

  • "I am never going to pass my final exams, no matter how hard I study"

(iv) Antisocial urges

Thoughts of indulging in some behaviors or actions that harm or lack consideration for the well being of others.

  • "I have these urges to go rob a bank or blackmail my neighbors for their money"

(v) Delusions

False beliefs that are strongly held and unchangeable in the face of refuting evidence and that are not consistent with the person's educational, social and cultural background.

The three main criteria for a belief to be considered a delusion are:

  • Certainty (held with complete confidence)
  • Incorrigibility (not changeable by proof to the contrary)
  • Impossibility or falsity of content (implausible, bizarre or patently untrue)
 DISORDERS OF PERCEPTIONS

  • Illusion: Misinterpretation of real external stimuli.

  • Hallucination: False sensory perception, externally.

  • Pseudohallucination: False sensory perception from within and having an insight.

  • Depersonalization: Feeling as if one is disconnected from reality, feeling detached from one's own thoughts and one's own physical body.

    "I sometimes drift into a dream-like state where I lose contact with my own self"

  • Derealization: Alteration in the perception or experience of the external world so that it seems unreal.

    "The world and everything around is nothing but just a dream"

questions.text: A 35-year-old female patient came with complaints of her hands turning very pale on exposure to cold for one month. The skin on her face and fingers is thickened and tight, and she has dilated capillaries over her face. She has a history of GERD. On investigation, she was found to have the following immunofluorescence pattern. Which of the following antibodies is most specific to this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario featuring the Raynaud phenomenon, GERD, telangiectasias and tightening of the skin in the face and hands is suggestive of CREST syndrome/ limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis, and anti-centromere antibodies are most specific for this disease. 

CREST syndrome consists of the following:

  • Calcinosis cutis
  • Raynaud’s phenomenon
  • Esophageal dysmotility
  • Sclerodactyly
  • Telangiectasia

Systemic sclerosis (SSc) is a chronic autoimmune disease. Progressive fibrosis due to the deposition of extracellular matrix components in different tissues and organs is the prominent feature of SSc. 

The characteristic features of SSc are vascular damage, inflammation, and the presence of specific autoantibodies. 

SSc is classified into two based on the extent of skin involvement.

  • Limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis / CREST syndrome
  • Diffuse cutaneous systemic sclerosis

In limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis (lcSSc), fibrosis in the skin of acral parts of the body, like the face and limbs (distal to elbow and knee), takes place. Skin fibrosis in limited type has a slow progression, but microcirculation disturbances like Raynaud's phenomenon start long before the skin symptoms and are associated with the involvement of the lungs and esophagus. 

Since it has late and slow organ involvement, it is associated with a good prognosis with a 10-year survival of over 90%. 

Antinuclear antibodies (ANA) are present in 90 - 95% of cases with SSc.

Autoantibodies specific to limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis include,

  • Anti- centromere
  • Anti-Th/To
  • Anti-U1-RNP
  • Anti-hUBF

Management is based on disease-modifying and organ-specific drugs. For peripheral vasculopathy and digital ulcers, calcium channel blockers like nifedipine amlodipine are used, and for refractory cases, phosphodiesterase 5 inhibitors are recommended.

Intravenous prostanoids are used for the healing process of digital ulcers and the improvement of microcirculation. The commonly used immunosuppressants for skin fibrosis are methotrexate, cyclophosphamide, and mycophenolate mofetil. When these drugs are ineffective or contraindicated, low-dose glucocorticosteroids or rituximab (anti-CD20) are used.

Related Pearl: Pattern of nuclear body suggests the type of antibody present in patient’s serum.

Five basic patterns of nuclear fluorescence is recognized for anti-nuclear antibodies:

Staining pattern Antigen
Homogenous or diffuse nuclear staining Antibodies to chromatin, histones, and occasionally double-stranded DNA
Rim or peripheral staining Antibodies to double-stranded DNA, and sometimes to nuclear envelope proteins
Speckled pattern

One of the most commonly observed patterns of fluorescence, the least specific. 

Antibodies to non-DNA nuclear constituents such as Sm antigen, ribonucleoprotein, and SS-A and SS-B reactive antigens.
Nucleolar pattern

Few discrete spots of fluorescence within the nucleus and represent antibodies to RNA.

Seen in systemic sclerosis.
Centromeric pattern

Seen in systemic sclerosis

Often contain antibodies specific for centromeres, which give rise to this pattern.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man from the eastern part of India presents with continuous fever, pallor, and splenomegaly. The bone marrow picture is shown below. Which of the following investigation would be the most appropriate in this case?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette and the slide showing macrophages infested with intracellular Leishmania donovani bodies point towards a diagnosis is visceral leishmaniasis or kala-azar. It can be established by the rk 39 antigen test. 

Leishmaniasis is a slowly progressing indigenous disease caused by a protozoan parasite of the genus Leishmania. It is transmitted by the bite of an infected female Phlebotomus sandfly which inoculates the flagellated promastigotes into the skin of the host in developing countries.

In human beings, the disease presents in four different forms with a broad range of clinical manifestations:

  • Visceral leishmaniasis, or kala-azar
  • Cutaneous leishmaniasis
  • Mucocutaneous leishmaniasis, and
  • Diffuse cutaneous leishmaniasis

The life cycle of Leishmania involves two forms,

  • The promastigote develops and lives extracellularly in the sandfly vector and
  • The amastigote multiplies intracellularly in the reticuloendothelial cells of the host.

Kala-azar is characterized by persistent fever, anemia, liver and spleen enlargement, and lymphadenopathy.

Diagnosis:

  • The microscopic demonstration of amastigotes from bone marrow is the gold standard for the diagnosis of Kala-azar.
  • Rapid diagnostic test: rk39 rapid diagnostic test and Kala-azar dipstick test strip. This is recommended by National Vector Borne Disease Control Programme (NVBDCP) in India.
  • Parasitological diagnosis: Demonstration of LD bodies in buffy coat smear, bone marrow, lymph node, or splenic aspirate is confirmatory.
  • Aldehyde test of Napier: Widely used for surveillance.
  • Serological tests for diagnosis: Rapid dipstick test, direct agglutination test, ELISA, indirect fluorescent antibody test, complement fixation test using Witebsky, Klingenstein and Kuhn (WKK) antigen.
  • Culture using NNN medium or Schneider's liquid medium to demonstrate promastigote.
  • Leishmanin /Montenegro test: Induration of 5mm or more after 48-72 hours indicated prior exposure to leishmanial parasite. It is a delayed hypersensitivity test. In active kala-azar, this test is negative and becomes positive usually 6-8 weeks after curing the disease.

Option B - Plasmodium lactate dehydrogenase (pLDH) antigen test is used in the diagnosis of malaria.

Option C - Sabin-Feldman dye test is a serological test done to detect toxoplasmosis.

Option D - ProSpec T is a commercially available ELISA test kit to detect Giardia-specific antigen 65.

The given images show amastigotes in the bone marrow.

Drugs used in the treatment of visceral leishmaniasis are sodium stibogluconate, miltefosine, and amphotericin. Liposomal amphotericin single dose 10mg/Kg IV is the first line of treatment in India.

Related Pearl: Important serological tests for the diagnosis of parasitic infections

Serological tests are helpful for the detection and surveillance of many protozoal and helminthic infections.

These tests are basically of 2 types:

  • Tests for antigen detection
  • Tests for antibody detection

questions.text: A 29-year-old man came with a history of jerky and hyperkinetic movements involving all parts of the body. His MRI shows marked atrophy of the caudate nucleus. There is a significant family history with successive generations having symptoms at earlier ages of onset. The pedigree chart is given below. Identify this genetic phenomenon.
questions.solution:
The given case scenario, with the family pedigree chart showing autosomal dominant inheritance points towards Huntington’s disease, and the genetic phenomenon seen here is anticipation. Anticipation refers to an earlier onset of disease in successive generations in a pedigree. 

Huntington's disease (HD) is a degenerative disease of the striate neurons. It is caused by an autosomal dominant inheritance of a trinucleotide repeat (CAG) in the HTT gene located on chromosome 4. This results in jerky, hyperkinetic movements called chorea and dementia. It is commonly seen in the 4th and 5th decades of life. Motor problems (the characteristic chorea) precede dementia. The HTT gene, on chromosome 4 encodes a protein called huntingtin. It has a stretch of repeats of the trinucleotide CAG. When the number of repeats is increased beyond normal, it is associated with Huntington's disease. More the repeats, earlier is its onset.

The caudate nucleus is dramatically atrophied, with accompanying atrophy of the putamen, and cortex. The lateral and 3rd ventricles may be dilated. There is a loss of striatal neurons in the caudate nucleus on microscopic examination. The medium-sized, spiny neurons that use GABA as their neurotransmitter, along with enkephalin, dynorphin, and substance P are affected. Protein aggregates containing huntingtin can be seen in the neurons of the striatum and cerebral cortex. The chorea can be treated with dopamine-blocking agents like tetrabenazine.

Other options:

Option A: Each mitochondrion contains many copies of mtDNA, where deleterious mutations of mtDNA may affect a few, but not all the copies of mtDNA. Hence, individuals may harbor both wild-type and mutant mtDNA. This is known as heteroplasmy. Thus, when a cell containing both normal and mutant mtDNA divides, the proportion of the normal and mutant mtDNA in the daughter cells is variable. This explains why the expression of disorders resulting from mtDNA mutations is variable.

Option B: Genetic heterogeneity refers to the phenomenon where mutations at several different loci produce the same trait.

Option C: Variable expressivity refers to a similar genotype but a varying phenotype. The trait will be present in all individuals carrying the mutant gene but is expressed differently among individuals. Eg: varying severity of disease with NF1 mutation (neurofibromatosis).

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy presents with developmental delay, short stature, a tendency to sunburn easily, and dry, scaly skin.  He has short and brittle hair and sparse eyebrows. Under polarized light microscopy of the hair strand, a pattern of alternating light and dark ‘tiger‐tail’ bands is seen.  What can be the  DNA repair defect in this case?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of trichothiodystrophy (TTD) which is caused by defective DNA Nucleotide Excision Repair (NER). Features like developmental delay, short stature, photosensitivity, and ichthyosis with short, brittle, and sparse hair are suggestive of the diagnosis. 

Trichothiodystrophy is an autosomal recessive disorder of DNA repair. Most patients carry mutations in the ERCC2 (XPD) gene of the nucleotide excision repair mechanism.

It is a multisystem disorder characterized by short, brittle, sulfur-deficient hair with a pattern of alternating light and dark ‘tiger‐tail’ bands under polarized light microscopy. Other features include photosensitivity, ichthyosis, developmental delay, and short stature.

questions.text: After intubating a patient for the first time, an intern was asked to confirm that the tube was inserted correctly into the trachea. Which of the following is not a sign of correct endotracheal intubation?

choices.text: Detection of end tidal CO2 by capnography
Visible condensation in the endotracheal tube

questions.solution:
Breath sounds in the epigastrium is a sign of esophageal intubation. Endotracheal intubation is characterized by the absence of breath sounds in the epigastrium.

Signs to confirm proper endotracheal intubation are:

  • Symmetrical chest rise
  • Presence of equal bilateral breath sounds over the chest
  • Absent breath sounds over the epigastrium
  • Visible condensation in the endotracheal tube
  • Large exhaled tidal volume
  • Appropriate compliance of the reservoir bag during manual ventilation.
  • Normal capnography

The most important and objective method to confirm the position of the endotracheal tube is capnography. 

Capnography is a non-invasive method of measurement and graphical display of partial pressure of carbon dioxide (CO2) in exhaled breath or the end-tidal CO2. It is the most reliable indicator of proper placement of the endotracheal tube (ETT) following intubation. Capnograph is the device used for measurement and capnogram represents the CO2 waveform displayed on the capnograph.

The given image shows the normal waveforms in a capnogram.

 

Esophageal intubation: initial end-tidal CO2 may be detected due to swallowed air but later becomes zero. There would be an absence of breath sounds bilaterally over the chest with the presence of breath sounds in the epigastrium.

Capnography in esophageal intubation:

 

If the ETT is inserted too deep, it can lead to endobronchial intubation. If inserted too shallow, it can lead to accidental extubation. Thus, an adequate-sized tube should be placed with its tip midway between the vocal cords and the carina.

Related Pearl: Signs of correct endotracheal intubation

  • Detection of end-tidal CO2 by capnography (Surest confirmation)
  • Symmetric chest rise
  • Bilateral breath sounds
  • Absence of breath sounds in the epigastrium
  • Visible condensation in the endotracheal tube
  • Large exhaled tidal volumes
  • Appropriate compliance of the reservoir bag during manual ventilation

The gradual rise of baseline and PETCO2 occurs when soda lime is exhausted.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy was brought with the finding as shown in the image below. Further evaluation revealed a chalky white, grey retinal mass with vitreous and subretinal seeding measuring 2mm. Which of the following regimen is commonly used​ in the treatment of this condition?
questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis in a 7-year-old child with a whitish pupillary reflex with the presence of a chalky white, grey retinal mass on fundus examination is retinoblastoma. As the disease falls under group C (vitreous and subretinal seeding <3 mm), it is treated with the commonly used three-drug CVE regimen consisting of vincristine, carboplatin, and etoposide.

Retinoblastoma is a malignant proliferation of immature retinal neural cells and is the most common intraocular malignancy in children. It is associated with mutations in the RB1 gene at chromosome 13q14. It is a tumor of a group called small round blue cell tumors because the immature retinal neural cells are seen as small round cells with large nuclei.

White pupillary reflex or leukocoria is the most common presenting feature, followed by a squint which is usually convergent. Rarely, the child may present with nystagmus and defective vision.

Image showing leukocoria of left eye. 

Histopathology of the tumor shows small round cells with large nuclei. Microscopic features of a well-differentiated tumor include Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes (highly specific to retinoblastoma), Homer-Wright rosettes, pseudorosettes, and fleurettes formation. Areas of necrosis and calcification can also be seen.

The histopathological image of retinoblastoma is shown below.

 
Treatment for group A to D diseases typically involves chemotherapy plus focal therapy. The commonly used three-drug regimen is the CVE regimen consisting of vincristine, carboplatin, and etoposide. Focal therapy includes cryotherapy, laser photocoagulation, thermotherapy, plaque radiotherapy, and external beam radiotherapy. Enucleation is the treatment of choice in group E disease. It is done when
  • The tumor involves more than half of the retina
  • The optic nerve is involved
  • Glaucoma is present and the anterior chamber is involved

In the stage of extraocular extension, the globe bursts through the sclera, usually near the limbus or the optic disc. This is followed by rapid fungation and involvement of extraocular tissues resulting in marked proptosis. Distant metastasis occurs through the lymphatic spread and the direct extension by continuity to the optic nerve and brain.

Pilocytic Astrocytomas:

  • Bipolar cells (tumor cells): thin, long hairlike processes that are GFAP - positive. 
  • Rosenthal fibers: eosinophilic corkscrew - shaped inclusions
  • Eosinophilic granular bodies: mulberry - like inclusions

  • Very densely cellular, with sheets of small primitive appearing small blue cells
  • Individual tumor cells have scant cytoplasm and hyperchromatic nuclei that are frequently elongated or crescent-shaped
  • Tumor cells form Homer - Wright rosettes (pseudorosettes) with a central neuropil

 

Ependymoma:

  • Ependymal rosettes: gland - like round or elongated structures that resemble the embryologic ependymal canal, with long, delicate processes extending into the lumen 
  • Perivascular pseudorosettes: perivascular nuclear - free zone consisting of thin ependymal processes radiating toward the central blood vessel

 

Oligodendroglioma:

  • Fried - egg appearance: sheets of regular cells with spherical nuclei containing finely granular chromatin (similar to normal oligodendrocytes) surrounded by a clear halo of vacuolated cytoplasm. 
  • Chicken - wire capillaries: a delicate network of anastomosing capillaries

 

Retinoblastoma: 

  • Composed of collections of small, round cells with hyperchromatic nuclei
  • Flexner - Wintersteiner rosettes: arrangements of a single layer of tumor cells around an apparent lumen
  • Homer - Wright rosettes: a ring of cells with an eosinophilic fibrillary center
  • Fleurettes: retinoblastoma cells that have undergone greater photoreceptor differentiation and group together as a bouquet. Fleurettes lack mitosis or necrosis.

questions.text: A young man is brought to the emergency department following a road traffic accident. He was driving the car when the accident occurred. On examination, it is noted that the injured leg is shortened. The image of the pelvis radiograph is shown below. Which of the following nerve is most commonly damaged in the given condition?
questions.solution:
The above radiograph shows that the femoral head of the left hip is displaced upwards and laterally, and the affected limb is in adduction. Also, the lesser trochanter is obscured. These features indicate posterior dislocation of the left hip joint. The nerve the most commonly injured in this type of dislocation is the sciatic nerve.

Posterior hip dislocation occurs when the knee of the passenger strikes the dashboard. The affected leg is shortened, and lies in an adducted, internally rotated and slightly flexed position.

Imaging shows the following features:

  • Upward dislocation of the femoral head
  • The size of the femoral head appears smaller compared to the unaffected side
  • Adduction of the affected limb.
  • The lesser trochanter may not be visible due to the internal rotation of the affected leg

Treatment- A pure hip dislocation should be reduced as early as possible to reduce the risk of osteonecrosis and subsequent osteoarthritis. Important maneuvers to reduce posterior hip dislocation are:

  • Rochester method
  • East Baltimore lift
  • Allis
  • Bigelow
  • Stimson

Complications of posterior hip dislocation are:

  • Injury to the sciatic nerve
  • Injury to the superior gluteal artery
  • Osteonecrosis of the femoral head
  • Secondary osteoarthritis
  • Myositis ossificans
  • Recurrent instability of the reduced dislocation

questions.text: A baby presented with abdominal pain and red currant jelly stools. On examination, a mass is palpated in the right upper abdomen. Abdominal ultrasound showed the target sign. Which of the following is the most common location of this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of abdominal pain, red currant jelly stool with a palpable mass along with the ultrasound showing the target sign is suggestive of intussusception. The most common location of intussusception is ileocolic.

Intussusception occurs when a portion of the bowel is telescoped into an adjacent segment. 

It can be seen in infants during the weaning period following the introduction of new food, vaccination, or upper respiratory tract infection. The currently approved rotavirus vaccines are associated with very minimal risk of intussusception. An area of enlarged submucosal Payer's patch acts as a lead point for intussusception.

Some lead points in children are Meckel's diverticulum, intestinal polyp, inflamed appendix, submucosal hemorrhage seen in Henoch-Schonlein purpura, and intestinal duplication cysts.

Patients present with cramping abdominal pain, palpable sausage-shaped abdominal mass, vomiting, and passage of red currant jelly stools.

Diagnosis is confirmed by abdominal ultrasound which shows target sign/bull's eye sign (shown below) and pseudokidney sign (seen longitudinally).

Barium enema shows a typical claw sign (shown below). This appearance is due to the barium in the lumen of the intussusceptum and in the intraluminal space.

 

Treatment of intussusception includes hydrostatic reduction by enema using contrast material or air. Surgical reduction is only done in the presence of refractory shock, suspected bowel necrosis or perforation, peritonitis, and multiple recurrences after hydrostatic reduction.

questions.text: In a presentation, you are explaining a cycle that depicts the management sequence of sudden disasters. Which step does number 5 in the image represent?
questions.solution:
The number 5 in the image represents preparedness in the disaster management cycle.

The correct sequence is:

1 - Response
2 - Rehabilitation
3 - Reconstruction
4 - Mitigation
5 - Preparedness


Disaster preparedness is a long-term plan with ongoing multisectoral activities. It includes the development of policies or programs for disaster management prevention, mitigation, preparedness, response, rehabilitation, and reconstruction. The measures taken will ensure that the country is capable to manage of all future emergencies efficiently.

Disaster response includes activities such as rescue and first aid, field care, triage, etc.

Disaster rehabilitation refers to measures that lead to the restoration of pre-disaster conditions. These measures include water supply restoration, food safety, basic sanitation, personal hygiene, and vector control.

Disaster mitigation measures are taken to prevent hazards from causing emergencies or to lessen the likely effects of emergencies. Some of these measures are:

  • Flood mitigation
  • Land-use planning
  • Improved building codes
  • Reduction and protection of vulnerable populations or structures.

Mitigation measures aim to reduce the vulnerability of the system and complements the disaster preparedness and response activities.

questions.text:
A 23-year-old primigravida at 25 weeks gestation, presents with right upper quadrant pain, nausea, and vomiting for the past 2 days. She was diagnosed with gestational hypertension 2 weeks back. Lab values are as follows. Which of the following other laboratory findings would be most likely seen in this patient?

Platelet count: 62000/mm3
Hematocrit: 26%
Blood glucose and cholesterol: Normal
Peripheral smear: Hemolytic red blood cells
questions.solution:
The typical presentation of right upper quadrant pain, nausea, vomiting, lab findings of thrombocytopenia, low hematocrit, and peripheral smear finding of hemolysis, suggests a diagnosis of  HELLP ( Hemolysis, Elevated Liver enzymes, Low Platelets) syndrome.

Elevated aspartate transaminase (AST) would be most likely seen in this patient with HELLP syndrome.

HELLP syndrome is an acronym that stands for: 

  • Hemolysis
  • Elevated Liver enzymes 
  • Low Platelets

Microangiopathic hemolysis manifests as:

  • Elevated serum lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) levels (Option B)
  • Reduced haptoglobin levels
  • Schizocytosis, spherocytosis, and reticulocytosis on peripheral blood smear

Elevation of AST and ALT (liver enzymes) levels occurs due to periportal hemorrhagic necrosis in the liver. Furthermore, hemorrhagic infarcts can extend to form a subcapsular hematoma that stretches the Glisson capsule. This results in characteristic epigastric/right quadrant pain and tenderness. It can be diagnosed using a CT or MRI. 

HELLP syndrome can also be associated with other complications such as eclampsia, placental abruption, stroke, coagulopathy, and pulmonary edema. 

Option A: Markedly elevated bilirubin levels are not likely seen in HELLP syndrome which characteristically does not present with marked hepatic dysfunction unlike acute fatty liver of pregnancy. Patients with acute fatty liver of pregnancy are likely to present with marked elevations of AST and bilirubin, hypoglycemia and hypocholesterolemia.

questions.text: A 44-year-old man with primary hyperparathyroidism is undergoing a focused parathyroidectomy. How can one confirm that adequate parathyroid gland has been removed?

choices.text: PTH falls >20% within 10 minutes of removal of gland
PTH falls >50% within 10 minutes of removal of gland
PTH falls >10% within 10 minutes of removal of gland
PTH falls >30% within 10 minutes of removal of gland

questions.solution:
Adequate removal of parthyroid gland can be confirmed by a fall of >50% in PTH levels within 10 mins of removal of the gland.

Most patients with primary hyperparathyroidism have a single adenoma. Therefore, they undergo a focused or minimally invasive parathyroidectomy where the localized abnormal parathyroid gland is removed. Once the gland is removed, the surgeon can ensure that there is no other hyperactive gland remaining by performing an intraoperative PTH assay as suggested by Miami criteria.

Miami criteria are based on the principle that the half-life of the PTH is 3-5 minutes. In a single-gland disease, once the gland is removed the PTH levels should drop to <50% of the preoperative PTH level within 10 minutes. However, if there is no drop in PTH level, then a multi-gland disease is suspected and the surgery is converted to a bilateral neck exploration.

The parathyroid is commonly transferred to the brachioradialis muscle post-surgery. When multiple parathyroids are resected, parathyroid tissue is transplanted to the non-dominant forearm. Pockets are made in the belly of the brachioradialis muscle, and one to two pieces of parathyroid tissue measuring 1 mm each are placed into each pocket. A total of 12 to 14 pieces are transplanted.

Related Pearl: Indications for parathyroidectomy in patients with asymptomatic primary HPT (2013-2014 NIH Consensus Conference Guidelines)

  • Serum calcium >1 mg/dL above the upper limit of normal
  • Renal: 
    • Reduction in creatinine clearance by 30%
    • 24-h urine calcium >400 mg/day
    • Presence of nephrolithiasis or nephrocalcinosis
  • Skeletal: 
    • Decreased bone mineral density (T score <-2.5)
    • Presence of vertebral fracture
  • Age <50 years

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman is diagnosed to have cervical cancer. MRI and PET-CT imaging reveal tumour extension up to the pelvic wall and involvement of the para-aortic lymph nodes. It also shows features suggestive of hydronephrosis. What is the best plan of management in this case?

choices.text: Modified radical hysterectomy with pelvic lymphadenectomy

questions.solution:
Cervical cancer involving the para-aortic lymph nodes is classified as Stage III C2 according to FIGO staging. Chemotherapy with radiation is the best plan of management in this case.

Note: If the patient just had carcinoma extension up to the pelvic wall and/or the presence of hydronephrosis, it would have been classified as Stage IIIB.

Related Pearl: Staging of Carcinoma Cervix

  • A: Microscopic lesion
    • A1 - stromal invasion <3mm depth
    • A2 - a stromal invasion of ≥3 and <5mm depth
  • B: Macroscopic lesion
    • B1 - stromal invasion ≥5mm depth & tumor size <2cm 
    • B2 - tumor size ≥2cm to <4cm 
    • B3 - tumor size ≥4cm 

Stage II - involves upper 2/3 of vagina

  • A: Extends to the upper two-thirds of the vagina without parametrial involvement
    • A1 - tumor size <4cm 
    • A2 - tumor size ≥4cm 
  • B: Extends to parametrium but not upto the pelvic wall.

  • B: Extends to the pelvic wall (hydronephrosis/non-functioning kidney)
  • C: Involvement of the pelvic and/or para-aortic lymph nodes, irrespective of the tumor size and extent

    • C2: para-aortic lymph node involved

  • B: Distant metastasis

Note: The involvement of vascular/lymphatic spaces does not change the staging. The lateral extent of the lesion is no longer considered.

Stage IIIB is the most common stage of presentation.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy with a history of cystic fibrosis is treated with an antibiotic for an infection in his lungs. This drug acts by inhibiting DNA gyrase and can cause tendon rupture. The prescribed antibiotic is?
questions.solution:
The prescribed antibiotic in the above clinical scenario is fluoroquinolone. It acts by inhibiting DNA gyrase and has a propensity to cause tendon rupture and arthropathy.

Normally, during replication, to prevent excessive positive supercoiling of the strands, DNA gyrase nicks double-stranded DNA and introduces negative supercoils. Fluoroquinolones, by inhibiting DNA gyrase (in gram-negative bacteria), result in the production of damaged DNA. This is finally digested by exonucleases, resulting in bactericidal action.

Fluoroquinolones inhibit topoisomerase IV in gram-positive bacteria.

Fluoroquinolones are used in the treatment of urinary tract infections, prostatitis, and gastrointestinal, and respiratory infections, and as a second-line drug in anti-tubercular therapy. They are avoided in children and pregnant women.

Adverse effects of fluoroquinolones are arthralgia, tendon rupture, Clostridium difficile colitis, dysglycemia, prolonged QT interval, rashes, hallucinations, delirium, and seizures.

Other options:

Option B: Tetracyclines binds to 30s ribosomes in susceptible organisms and inhibit protein synthesis in them.

Option C: Beta-lactam antibiotics cause cell wall synthesis inhibition.

Option D: Sulfonamides cause inhibition of folic acid synthesis in susceptible organisms.

questions.text: A carpenter sustained a hit to his thumb by a hammer while working. Following this, he developed a poorly localised dull aching pain.  What is the type of nerve fibre carrying this pain?
questions.solution:
The poorly localised dull aching pain experienced after a hit by a heavy object like a hammer is carried by C fibres.

C-dorsal root fibres are unmyelinated fibres found mainly in the deep somatic structures such as the muscles and joints. They are activated by thermal, mechanical or chemical stimuli that result in poor localization and slow, dull pain. The conducting rate of these fibres is 0.5 to 2 m/s.

Another type of nerve fibre responsible for pain sensation is Aδ fibres. They are myelinated fibres responsible for first pain also called fast pain (conduction velocity 6 to 30 m/s). These fibres get activated under thermal or mechanical stimuli and cause a short-lasting pricking type of pain that can be localized. They are mainly found in superficial structures such as the skin.

Other Options:

Option A: Aα fibre conducts proprioception and somatic motor at a rate of 70–120m/s.

Option B: Aβ fibre conducts touch and pressure at a rate of 30-70 m/s.

Option C: B fibres are preganglionic autonomic fibres conducting at the rate of 3–15m/s.
